image.altText: Stephen hugging his two daughters Chloe and Jess.

props.synopsis: Despite moving to Australia as a child and raising his whole family here, a criminal conviction over methamphetamine means Stephen is facing deportation to a country where he has no ties.

title.children: Stephen served his time after being caught with meth. Instead of going home, he's being deported

image.altText: A long queue of people stand in line with their luggage at Perth Airport.

props.synopsis: A refuelling issue at Perth Airport which had grounded dozens of domestic and international flights is resolved, but many passengers are unhappy.

title.children: Passengers vent fury after Perth Airport flight cancellations leave them without refunds

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a dark hoodie looks into camera with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: The residents of Rainbow Lodge have committed multiple crimes and been in and out of prison for decades. For many, its program is their last chance to take responsibility for their actions and prove they're ready for the outside world – but one slip-up could land them back inside.

title.children: Meet the residents of Rainbow Lodge, the broken men with nowhere else to go

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a suit with grey hair speaks behind a lectern in front of a blue screen.

props.synopsis: Officers from China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) confront Richard Marles at an international security conference after the Australian minister used a speech to call out China for its recent confrontations with Australian naval forces.

title.children: Deputy PM Richard Marles confronted by Chinese PLA officers at security conference in Singapore

image.altText: Jordy sits on the bank of a river in rural Queensland, with a friend wearing a colourful cap.

props.synopsis: The rise of social media and smartphones has coincided with an accelerating decline in teenagers' mental health — and researchers are trying to figure out whether the technology is to blame.

title.children: Many of us spend hours a day in a 'second world' on our phones. What's it really doing to our mental health?

image.altText: An older man in a suit with glasses looks serious in front of a dark blue curtain.

props.synopsis: An increase in pornographic deepfake images generated by artificial intelligence is prompting laws from the federal government to ban the sharing of non-consensual digitally created and altered sexually explicit material.

title.children: Sharing of deepfake pornography to carry a six-year prison term, government says

image.altText: A graphic showing four Ozempic pens, three of which have the brand name ripped out

props.synopsis: Yet again, the manufacturers of a wildly popular drug, taken by millions of women globally, have not collected data on what this drug might do to a woman's reproductive organs or offspring.

title.children: Ozempic 'oops babies' should make women think twice about weight loss drugs

image.altText: A young blonde woman named Ariel Bombara sitting while being interviewed.

props.synopsis: A system designed to keep women safe seemingly follows all the right procedures and somehow two women are shot dead in their own home. What needs to change to fix it?

title.children: Two Perth women slain in their own home, yet police say all correct procedures were followed. How do we fix this?

image.altText: Maria Elena Rios with her saxophone in a park

props.synopsis: In Mexico, an untold number of women are murdered, kidnapped, or subjected to unspeakable violence at the hands of men. These are just some of their stories. WARNING: Some readers might find details in this story distressing.

title.children: María Elena was writing an email when a stranger poured acid on her. Then began the fight of her life

image.altText: A brown snake with its head reared and tongue out

props.synopsis: A snake doesn't have to be alive to bite and kill you. So how can this be, and how long can they remain dangerous after they've wriggled off this mortal coil?

title.children: Decapitated but still dangerous: How a dead snake can still cause a lethal 'bite'

image.altText: Em Rusciano in yellow and black houndstooth jacket over yellow top, with ornate jewelled earrings

props.synopsis: Em Rusciano burst onto the national stage as an advocate for ADHD women. But when she asked a doctor to investigate autism, it was a flat-out no. Ahead of a national tour, she shares the reality of being a late-diagnosed neurodivergent, perimenopausal woman.

title.children: Em Rusciano discovered her ADHD and autism in her 40s. Then came perimenopause

image.altText: Two women hold a bucket between them as they walk along a South Korean island followed by a woman in a cart.;

props.synopsis: After a bombardment of shells in January, residents on the South Korean island of Yeongpyeong are anxiously waiting for another attack. Some wonder: could it happen again?

title.children: 'North Korea won't give in': Living in the shadow of a giant, this island is building bunkers

image.altText: butterflies seen pinned to a black background.

props.synopsis: In early 1987, the Melbourne Museum discovered the loss of more than 800 specimens of rare Australian butterflies. When other museums reported similar thefts, the trail led to a former champion skier trying to cope with a crumbling marriage.

title.children: A former ski champion visited multiple Australian museums — and walked out with hundreds of dead butterflies in his pockets

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed with a serious look on his face with th Hard quiz logo in the top left corner

props.synopsis: Oh, you're back? Something to prove after last week's effort? Let's see what you've got.

title.children: Fancy yourself a trivia buff? Let's see about that. It's time to play, HARD!

image.altText: A young Papua New Guinea man wearing a black hoodie and sunglasses looks sombrely out over a large pile of rocks.

props.synopsis: Survivors of a colossal landslide in Papua New Guinea's highlands have spoken about the warning signs they noticed hours before it flattened a village, killing upwards of 160 people.

title.children: Survivors of Papua New Guinea landslide say they heard two large cracks before mountainside fell on village

image.altText: Composite image of people holding wineglasses and the actor Keira Knightly smelling a wine

props.synopsis: Amid challenging conditions in the local wine industry, an "exciting" cultural shift is taking place on and offline in how wine is being consumed and talked about.

title.children: Tiktok sommeliers and Keira Knightley articles: how the online wine culture is shifting

image.altText: A man and woman in old-fashioned clothing look at something burning in front of them.

props.synopsis: This era-hopping sci-fi romance starring Léa Seydoux takes inspiration from a Henry James novella and turns it into a head-spinning, two-and-a-half-hour odyssey.

title.children: Léa Seydoux dazzles in The Beast, which captures the strangeness of watching AI's unstoppable expansion

image.altText: woman poses for pictures at a lookout

props.synopsis: For those who choose to live in student housing, rents for a single room can often be more than the price of a whole apartment, with some international students saying the prices are "insane".

title.children: The trouble with university student accommodation and plans to build more of it

image.altText: A heater on the floor with two feet warming up next to it. The feet have socks on

props.synopsis: Winter is here, and experts say there are ways to stay warm while saving money on your power bill. One of them is to avoid setting the heater temperature too high.

title.children: What's the most cost-effective way to heat your home this winter? Here's what experts recommend

image.altText: the rubble after a house explosion in whalan western sydney on 010624

props.synopsis: A delicate search and rescue operation is under way in Western Sydney for a woman feared trapped beneath rubble after an explosion destroyed a townhouse in a complex on Saturday afternoon.

title.children: Woman feared trapped underneath rubble after explosion destroys home in Sydney's west

image.altText: Harley Reid stands with Eagles teammates after AFL loss to Saints.

props.synopsis: Harley Reid's hopes of winning the AFL Rising star award hang in the balance following West Coast's 14-point defeat to St Kilda, while Geelong snaps a four-match losing streak with its win over a gallant Richmond.

title.children: 'There's nothing in it': Harley Reid faces potential ban as Eagles coach defends young star

image.altText: View of a mountainous peak.

props.synopsis: Search teams looking for a walker missing since Wednesday in the remote Tasmanian wilderness say they have located a body and it appears the man has fallen to his death.

title.children: Hiker dies during solo trek in Tasmanian wilderness

image.altText: A mock up of the live nation and ticketmaster logos on a phone

props.synopsis: According to Ticketmaster's public filing, the company first identified "unauthorised activity" on May 20, a week before the post on social media.

title.children: Ticketmaster confirms data breach days after Home Affairs launches investigation

image.altText: A man stands in a crowd of Israeli supporters holding a yellow and black signs with the words 'Bring them Home' on it

props.synopsis: Benjamin Netanyahu remains opposed to a ceasefire, with his government describing the proposal as a "non-starter".

title.children: 'Non-starter': Benjamin Netanyahu rejects growing calls from families of hostages to accept ceasefire proposal

image.altText: A white man with short brown hair and glasses sitting in an office. He's wearing a shirt and tie

props.synopsis: Julian Hill is one of a number of MPs calling for a complete ban on the use of genetic tests in life insurance assessments.

title.children: An MP's daughter nearly died from a common genetic condition. When he went to get tested, the doctor's response shocked him

image.altText: Two men walk across a Melbourne CBD bridge with a COVID vaccination poster in view

props.synopsis: The state government will be forced to publicly release thousands of pages of secret briefings behind the state's lockdowns, following an almost four-year Freedom of Information battle.

title.children: Victorian government forced to release documents behind lockdown decisions

image.altText: A red and green gradient lights up the night sky.

props.synopsis: May saw Perth stunned by acts of chilling violence that sent shock waves far beyond the city. But there were also moments of quiet beauty in WA, and our photographers were on hand to capture it all.

title.children: From glowing night skies and scenes of immense courage, these are WA's best photos of the month

image.altText: A middle-aged white man in a suit shakes hands with a middle-aged black man in a colourful shirt in a large hall.

props.synopsis: The party of the late Nelson Mandela receives just 40.27 per cent of the vote in national parliamentary elections, down from 57.7 per cent in 2019, as supporters abandon it due to anger over joblessness, inequality and power shortages.

title.children: Nelson Mandela's party in coalition talks with 'everybody and anybody' after losing majority for first time in 30 years

image.altText: Hawks coach Sam Mitchell during the round 12 match against the Crows.

props.synopsis: Hawthorn coach Sam Mitchell blasts a racist social media post directed at one of his players, saying if it came from a Hawks fan they are unwelcome at the AFL club.

title.children: 'We don't want you': Sam Mitchell decries racism after social media abuse of Hawks player

image.altText: Keith Davis stands outside the Royal Adelaide Hospital.

props.synopsis: Keith Davis and Kerry Jordan — who were injured onboard a Singapore Airlines flight from London to Singapore that encountered severe turbulence — have returned home to Adelaide via a medical evacuation flight.

title.children: 'Tough days ahead' says Australian couple injured on Singapore Airlines flight, as they return home to Adelaide

image.altText: two women sit on an outdoor couch

props.synopsis: One photographer looks at three households embracing communal living to see if Australians can adapt their way of life as housing becomes ever more unaffordable.

title.children: Moving back home, co-housing, and boarders. How three households embraced communal living

image.altText: a photo collage of a young indigenous man

props.synopsis: As the coroner tries to get to the bottom of what happened to the 27-year-old, the case remains short on strong evidence while abundant with theories and claims of criminal conduct.

title.children: Guns, drugs and a 'feast' of lies: Straight answers difficult to find for missing man's devastated family

image.altText: Trump looks down frowning while wearing a suit in court

props.synopsis: Donald Trump has been found guilty in a hush money trial, but his legal woes are far from over. As he continues his bid to retake the White House, here’s a status update on his other court cases.

title.children: Your guide to Donald Trump's other criminal court cases following his guilty verdict

image.altText: Dozens of hens with glossy brown feathers and red plump combs under a clear blue sky.

props.synopsis: With Australian officials closely monitoring local outbreaks of avian influenza, and another highly pathogenic strain wreaking havoc overseas, experts in infectious disease and public health say this is how we should prepare for the possibility of a future pandemic.

title.children: As avian flu spreads around the world, experts say 'we're nowhere near prepared' for a future pandemic

image.altText: Robert Picketon

props.synopsis: The Correctional Service of Canada said in statement that Pickton, an inmate of Port-Cartier Institution in the province of Quebec, died in hospital following injuries in the May 19 assault.

title.children: Canadian serial killer Robert Pickton dies after prison assault aged 74
